Name: Israel, Occupied Palestinian Territories Complex Emergency-2014
Summary__c: Hostilities between Israel and Hamas and other armed groups in the Gaza Strip escalated on July 7; fighting further intensified when Israel began a ground operation in Gaza on July 17th. The hostilities further exacerbated the serious humanitarian situation of the civilian population in Gaza, which is already dealing with chronic difficulties largely brought about by restrictions on the movement of people and goods and the fragility of infrastructure and basic services. On August 26, a ceasefire was agreed between Hamas and the Israeli government.

Name: Guatemala Drought-2016
Summary__c: The ongoing El Niño phenomenon has worsened existing drought conditions, affecting 110,000 families in Guatemala’s dry corridor. Most of those affected work in agriculture, reporting crop loss of 50 percent or more. Families estimate that food reserves will be depleted by April 2016.

Name: Myanmar Population Movement-2015
Summary__c: Heavy fighting between government troops and MNDAA continues in Kokang region, Shan state. According to unconfirmed media reports, between 40,000 and 100,000 people have fled across the border to China; 13,000 have fled through Lashio town.

Name: Pakistan Monsoon Floods-2014
Summary__c:
• Heavy monsoon rains produced flash floods along four  rivers in eastern Pakistan during the first week of September.  The flooding caused homes to collapse in the Punjab, Gilgit Baltistan and Azad Jammu & Kashmir  regions and  triggered landslides, resulting in loss of life, damage to property and infrastructure, and  agricultural and livestock losses.
  • However, according to the latest flood alert from the Pakistan Meteorological Department, all the major rivers are back to flowing at their normal state of flow and flood levels are decreasing.
  • The flooding in Pakistan has affected 2.3 million people and caused more than 350 deaths and 620 injuries in affected regions of the country. More than 47,000 houses have been destroyed or damaged and millions of crops have been wiped out, which will have large implications for food security and livelihoods.
  • The greatest needs in the flood affected areas of the country include food, emergency shelter, health, and water and sanitation.

Name: Chile Floods-2015
Summary__c: Heavy rainfall and consequent river overflow, flash floods and landslides affected the Atacama and Antofagasta regions in the north of Chile over 24-25 Mar 2015

Name: Peru Floods-2014
Summary__c: Beginning in September 2014, floods, heavy rains, hail and landslides affected several parts of Peru including Arequipa, Loreto, Cusco, Amazonas, and San Martin. As of the beginning of February 2015, various districts of the forest areas were under a state of emergency as a result of weeks of rains.

Name: Ecuador Floods-2015
Summary__c: Heavy rainfall affected several areas of Ecuador starting in mid-March 2015, triggering river overflow and landslides in several provinces. As of 23 Mar, damage to houses and infrastructure as well as casualties had been reported in most provinces, with at least seven people killed and another five missing in Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas and Pichincha provinces, due to landslides.

Name: Argentina Floods-2015
Summary__c: The heaviest rain in decades pounded much of central and western Argentina at the beginning of March 2015, triggering flooding and prompting evacuations

Name: Philippines Typhoon Hagupit-2014
Summary__c: Typhoon Hagupit (locally known as “Ruby”) has gained strength in the western Pacific and is projected to intensify further as it heads towards the Philippines. The typhoon has maximum sustained winds of 190 kilometers per hour and wind gusts of up to 235 kilometers per hour. It is expected to make landfall on December 6th.

Name: Central America Drought-2015
Summary__c: Since the start of the May-August rainfall season, many parts of Central America have received belowaverage rainfall, which has depleted soil moisture and negatively affected crops. The Salvadorean Red Cross is conducting assessments of the impact of an ongoing drought. The drought caused losses of 4.7 million quintals of maize and 52,158 quintals of beans and affected 102,609 producers, according to Minister of Agrulcture. According to teh minister, the loss of corn is about 25% of national production.

Name: Serbia Floods-2016
Summary__c: Heavy rainfalls occurred in the western part of Serbia on 6-7 March 2016, which caused the Western and Southern Morava rivers to spill over. A state of emergency was declared in the municipalities of Arilje and Lučani since the rivers Bjelica and Moravica inundated local roads, residential buildings and other infrastructures such as factories and schools.

Name: Mauritania Food Insecurity-2015
Summary__c: This Food Security crisis is a regional crisis affecting the Sahel area.

Name: Test-Enzigma-Disaster1-2015
Summary__c: Only for Testing purpose

Name: Test-Enzigma-Disaster2-2015
Summary__c: Only for Testing Purpose

Name: Argentina Floods-2015
Summary__c: Flooding in Argentina. Corporation interested in donating to responding ($25k). Only possibility is through grant letter to national society. Stacy and Paul to follow up.

Name: Colombia Population Movement-2015
Summary__c: Colombia refugees in Venezuala are being sent back to Colombia. DREF issued today. Ops meeting to be scheduled.

Name: Pacific Tropical Cyclone Pam-2015
Summary__c:
• Category five Tropical Cyclone Pam is moving through the South Pacific Ocean and has caused significant damage in the Solomon Islands and Vanuatu over the past two days.
  • In the Solomon Islands assessments of damage are on-going while heavy rain is causing flooding and landslides. Communications continue to be a challenge in all provinces.
  • In Vanuatu there are reports of damage to permanent structures and many informal shelters are completely destroyed. There are also reports of damage to health facilities, loss of running water and power outages. Many islands are still cut off from communications so the full scale of the impact is not yet known

Name: Zimbabwe Food Insecurity-2015
Summary__c: A slow onset of the rainy season was followed by severe flooding that destroyed crops. This situation was followed, and exacerbated, by a long dry spell, resulting in a crop yield below the 5 year average. Zimbabwe Vulnerability Assessment Committee report estimated 16% of Zimbabwe's rural population are food insecure and 1,500,000 people wil lbe in need of food assistance at the peak of the hunger period. Coping mechanisms are severely strained, and social safety-net interventions by the Government and partners are limited.

Name: Mongolia Extreme Winter Condition-2015
Summary__c: Mongolia is experiencing what is locally referred to as "dzud" conditions: extreme winter weather which causes large numbers of livestock to die. The National Emergency Management Authority (NEMA) has reported that snow has covered 90 per cent of the total territory with conditions getting more severe, with 50 soums (districts) are in dzud1 state and 120 soums are on the edge of entering dzud state.

Name: Tanzania Cholera Outbreak-2015
Summary__c: Cholera outbreak

Name: Philippines Typhoon and Floods-2015
Summary__c: On December 14, 2015, Typhoon Melor (known locally as Nona) struck the Philipines over Northern Samar, moving westward, finally dissipating on December 19, 2015. The worst damage was recorded over Northern Samar, Sorsogon and Oriental Mindoro. Following Melor, Tropical Depression Twenty Three made landfall over eastern Mindanao on 18 December, bringing with it torrential rain, floods and landslides. Both Melor and Twenty Three caused heavy rainfall throughout the Philippines, worsening the situation for many farming communities.

Name: Malawi Food Insecurity-2015
Summary__c: Food insecurity

Name: Global Zika Virus Outbreak-2016
Summary__c: On February 1, 2016, the WHO Director-General declared the Zika virus a "Public Health Emergency of International Concern." As of March 9, 2016, 31 countries and territories in the Americas have reported active transmission of the mosquito-borne Zika virus infection.  In addition, five countries and territories in the Pacific and one country in Africa have reported active transmission of the virus.

Name: El Salvador Drought-2016
Summary__c: As a result of the El Niño phenomenon, Central America began experiencing dry weather conditions in mid-2015. Low rainfall has led to water shortages from traditional water sources like wells and streams, affecting subsistence farmers' outputs and leading to food insecurity.

Name: Malawi, Mozambique Floods-2015
Summary__c: Heavy seasonal rainfall starting in December 2014 has caused flooding in Southern Africa, specifically affecting Malawi and Mozambique.

Name: Pakistan Floods-2015
Summary__c: Floods in Pakistan

Name: Ethiopia Drought-2016
Summary__c: Ethiopia Drought

Name: Ecuador Earthquake-2016
Summary__c: On April 16, a powerful 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck the northwest coast of Ecuador at 6:58pm local time. The epicenter was 27 kilometers south-southeast of the small coastal town of Muisne, at a depth of 20 kilometers.  The earthquake resulted in more than 660 deaths and injured more than 4,000 people, leading the Government of Ecuador to declare a state of emergency in 6 provinces: Esmeraldas, Manabí, Santa Elena, Guayas, Santo Domingo and Los Ríos.

Name: Gambia Food Insecurity-2015
Summary__c: This food security crisis is a regional crisis affecting the Sahel Region.

Name: Lesotho Food Insecurity-2016
Summary__c: Food Insecurity

Name: Fiji Tropical Cyclone Winston-2016
Summary__c: On February 20, Tropical Cyclone Winston--a category 5 severe storm--made landfall in Fiji, causing widespread destruction. The storm impacted all geographical divisions of Fiji, and the Government of Fiji has declared a 30-day state of disaster.  The Government of Fiji estimates that the storm may have impacted up to 350,000 people, with more than 50,000 people displaced into emergency shelters.  Initial assessments indicate that emergency relief, shelter, water and sanitation and health are the immediate response priorities.

Name: Chile Earthquake-2015
Summary__c: 8.3 Earthquake, infrastructure and shelter damage. PADRU has not released DREF nor appeal yet. Roberto thinks possible DREF will be launched. Not heard of donor interest yet. Comms potentially looking to write a story about preparedness - Helen to follow up.

Name: Namibia Food Insecurity-2015
Summary__c: Food Insecurity

Name: Haiti & Dominican Republic Cholera-2014
Summary__c: Since October 2010, when the first cholera cases were reported in Haiti in more than 100 years, the cholera caseload in Haiti and the Dominican Republic has increased dramatically.  Cholera has killed more than 8,500 people in Haiti and 454 people in the Dominican Republic since 2010, and more than 650,000 Haitians and 30,000 Dominicans have contracted the disease during this period. In 2012, the governments of Haiti and the Dominican Republic developed ten-year national action plans outlining investments and interventions necessary to eliminate the transmission of cholera by 2022.  Agencies working in support of the respective national plans, including the Red Cross, formed a coalition to coordinate cholera response efforts.  In recent years, Red Cross efforts have contributed to a reduction in the number of cholera cases in Haiti and the Dominican Republic.  However, eradication of the disease requires further reducing the number of cholera cases, increasing awareness of beneficial hygiene and sanitation practices, increasing national capacity to detect and control cholera outbreaks, reducing the risk of contamination, and supporting treatment of cholera patients.

Name: Vietnam Floods-2015
Summary__c: Monitoring.

Name: Ecuador Volcanic Eruption-2015
Summary__c: 8/18: No appeals/DREF yet. Received Sitreps.

Name: Kenya Cholera Outbreak-2015
Summary__c:
Initial signs of a cholera outbreak were found in a surveillance system in Nairobi. Since December 2014, 21 counties have reported cases, with a total of 5,564 cases and 113 deaths. Ministry of Health has a lead management role in outbreak control (management of cases and prevention of new infections), but with challenges in control efforts, the Ministry of Health has formally requested by KRCS's support in scaling up these efforts by increasing trained personnel dedicated to epidemic control in 10 counties. 

Emergency appeal was launched on 9/2.

Name: Central America Tropical Storm Agatha-2010
Summary__c: On May 29, the first Pacific Tropical Storm of 2010, Agatha, quickly devolved into Tropical Depression Agatha in the afternoon of May 29. The weather system brought unusually heavy rainfall to Central America. El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras have been particularly impacted, with Guatemala experiencing the highest amount of rainfall since 1949, with precipitation ranging from 8 to 14 inches between May 25 and 28. More than 150,000 people have already been evacuated from their homes in the region. The situation is still developing as rain continues to fall, leading to more flooding and landslide risk.

Name: DR Congo Population Movement-2013
Summary__c: Since December 2012, refugees escaping violence in the Central African Republic (CAR) have been migrating into Equateur, a province in the north of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). According to the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, more than 30,000 refugees from CAR are now residing in DRC. The population remains in flux and the numbers could increase due to the overthrow of the CAR government by rebels in March 2013.  Immediate needs include temporary shelter, food, water and reconnecting separated family members. Assessments have also highlighted health, nutrition and protection for the displaced population as additional needs.

Name: Hostage Crisis in Beslan, North Ossetia-2004
Zimbabwe Food Insecurity-2012
Summary__c: The food security crisis in Zimbabwe is affecting 1.6 million people primarily in the southern regions of the country. Below-normal rainfall is forecast for the southern regions of Zimbabwe throughout the coming season which may worsen conditions in the regions already affected by drought. Droughts over the past two years, along with poor agriculture practices and limited access to supplies, have contributed to a smaller harvest this year. Assessments indicate an immediate need for food, agriculture support and clean water.

Name: DPR Korea (North Korea) Floods-2011
Summary__c: Floods in the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (DPRK) caused by months of heavy rainfall and a recent typhoon have destroyed homes, infrastructure and crops, leaving more than 25,000 people homeless.More than 45,000 people are affected in the DPRK. While flood damage is reported throughout the country, south and north Hwanghae provinces have been the worst hit by repeated flooding, leaving an already vulnerable population in a critical condition.

Name: Nigeria Floods-2012
Summary__c: Between July and October 2012, the worst flooding Nigeria has experienced in 40 years has affected 7 million people, killed 363, and displaced 2.1 million. Flooding has affected 33 of Nigeria’s 36 states, with the greatest impact currently in the southern parts of the country.  Flooding has destroyed crops and damaged roads and bridges making transportation of goods to communities extremely difficult. In some flooded areas, food prices have increased by 30 to 70 percent resulting in food insecurity. Displaced people are living with host families or in camps and schools, many of which do not have adequate sanitation facilities and drinking water. This situation is also preventing schools from functioning normally.

Name: Mexico Floods-2011
Summary__c: Heavy rains associated with various recent tropical depressions and storms have caused flooding in more than 850 communities in the southeast Mexican states of Tabasco and Chiapas.

Name: New Zealand Earthquake-2011
Summary__c:
A 6.3 magnitude earthquake struck near Christchurch, New Zealand on February 22. There was widespread damage, including collapsed buildings in the city center and damage to roads and bridges.  Authorities have reported 172 confirmed deaths, but predict that this figure may rise as remains are recovered from the rubble and identified. They have confirmed the identity of 140 victims so far. More than 100,000 homes were damaged, representing 60% of Christchurch residences.  Approximately 2,000 people were displaced to evacuation centers.  Government authorities have extended the state of national emergency until April 18.  Although outages remain within the Christchurch city center, 99% of households outside of that area have power.  
The New Zealand government estimates that the direct cost of the earthquake to the government is US$4.3 billion and warns that the catastrophe will negatively impact the country's struggling economy.

Name: Costa Rica Floods-2010
Summary__c: Since November, torrential rains have hit Costa Rica, triggering landslides, floods and the movement of thousands of people to shelters along the Pacific coast and in the Central Valley. Floods have also destroyed infrastructure including roadways, bridges, water systems and housing.

Name: Indonesia Tsunami & Volcanic Eruption-2010
Summary__c: Two disasters struck Indonesia on October 25. Following a 7.7 magnitude earthquake, a 9-foot tsunami hit the Mentawai Islands off the coast of Sumatra, travelling at least a quarter of a mile inland and destroying the coastline in many locations. On the island of Java, the Mount Merapi volcano has been erupting since  October 25, killling 104 people.

Name: Nepal Diarrhea Outbreak-2010
Summary__c: Diarrhea is endemic to Nepal due to unsafe hygiene practices, open defecation and lack of access to safe drinking water.  Additionally, poor health infrastructure, surveillance and laboratory facilities mean that highly transmissible diseases like cholera cannot be detected quickly at the local level, resulting in a delay in diagnosis and management, leading to high mortality and morbidity rates.  Statistics over the past five years indicate a trend of increasing cases, culminating in the 2009 outbreak in western Nepal that claimed an estimated 371 lives and affected approximately 67,000 people.  Given previous trends, an immediate and sustained intervention is required to prevent an outbreak with a number of deaths similar to or higher than those during previous monsoon seasons.

Name: El Salvador Floods-2009
Summary__c: On November 7 and 8, El Salvador experienced significant floods and mudslides due to the combined effects of Tropical Storm Ida and a low pressure weather system. Overflowing rivers destroyed houses, health centers, crops and infrastructure.

Name: Java Indonesia Earthquake-2009
Summary__c: The earthquake measuring 7.4 on the Richter scale hit Tasikmalaya district in West Java province in the afternoon of 2 September.

Name: Bolivia Floods-2012
Summary__c: A La Niña weather phenomenon has created irregular rain patterns throughout South America, causing serious flooding in Bolivia.  Floods have affected virtually all of the country.  More than 13,000 families (or 65,000 people) are affected. The government declared a state of emergency in February. Rains are predicted to continue into April. Bolivia is also experiencing an outbreak of dengue fever and the Red Cross is working to address water and sanitation issues caused by the floods to curb the spread of the disease. Assessments show that the most immediate needs of affected families are for relief items, rehabilitation of water and sanitation systems to prevent further spread of dengue and support for livelihoods as many crops have been lost.

Name: Peru Floods-2012
Summary__c: Hydro-meteorological disturbances and La Niña weather phenomenon have worsened Peru’s annual rainy season, causing major flooding across the country. An estimated 650,000 people throughout Peru have been affected by the flooding and roads have sustained heavy damage, making relief distributions challenging. On March 29, the government declared a state of emergency for three-quarters of Peru’s departments. In the most affected department of Loreto, more than 1,800 families have been evacuated to emergency shelters. Initial needs assessments show that the most immediate needs of affected families include relief items, water and sanitation services, disease prevention efforts, and improvements to the conditions of emergency shelters.

Name: Philippines Typhoon Bopha-2012
Summary__c: Typhoon Bopha made landfall on the eastern coast of Mindanao Island in the Philippines on December 4, 2012.  The storm caused flooding and landslides, destroying homes, agriculture and infrastructure across coastal areas. Typhoon Bopha has affected 6.2 million people, killing 1,043 and leaving 841 missing. The storm damaged or destroyed over 130,000 houses and displaced over 986,000 people.  Destruction of roads and bridges is hindering response efforts to the most affected areas. Flooding and landslides have contaminated water supplies and 67 percent of health facilities in three provinces were damaged by the storm.

Name: West & Central Africa Floods-2009
Summary__c: A heavier than normal rainy season in West and Central Africa has caused serious flooding in 16 countries. Beginning in early September the flooding worsened, affecting more than 600,000 people in Benin, Central African Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea Bissau, Liberia, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone and Togo. The rains have caused 159 deaths and considerable damage to homes and infrastructure, leaving thousands homeless. The number of people affected is expected to climb as rains continue.

Name: Thailand Floods-2011
Summary__c: More than 3.4 million people are still affected by Thailand’s worst flooding in more than five decades. Many communities across the country have been isolated for weeks, relying on local authorities and organizations like the Thai Red Cross for basic assistance. Thai authorities are working to channel water from flooded Bangkok into the Gulf of Thailand. But the sheer volume of water and seasonal high tides has resulted in extensive flooding and the forced evacuation of a growing number of districts in the densely populated city of 12 million. Thousands of people have been forced to leave their homes and move into government shelters while one million people have become unemployed as floods engulfed factories and agricultural land.

Name: Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan Population Movement-2010
Summary__c: Since April 2010, political upheaval has led to ethnic clashes have escalated between Kyrgyz and Uzbeks living in southwest Kyrgyzstan.  An interim government had announced a referendum on a new constitution for the end of June.  Violent clashes, including looting and targeted killings. The violence has led an estimated 375,000 residents to flee their homes, particularly in the cities of Osh and Jalalabad.

Name: Paraguay Drought-2012
Summary__c: A La Niña weather phenomenon has created irregular rain patterns throughout South America, causing a serious drought in Paraguay. The drought has hit southern Paraguay in one of the most important agricultural regions of the country. The government declared a food security emergency in January. It reports that 8 of the country’s 17 departments are under a serious drought, with agriculture production reduced by 30 to 50 percent. Small farmers and food producers are particularly hard hit; more than 263,800 households are experiencing crop loss and are in need of food.  The most immediate needs for the short term are for safe water, food items and seeds for immediate planting. The drought has limited the movement of food and commercial shipping along rivers due to low water levels and led to a lack of safe water for household use.

Name: Tajikistan Mudslides and Floods-2009
Summary__c: Heavy rainfall in April and May resulted in flooding in various parts of Tajikistan, killing 26 and affecting 12,000 people. It also significantly affected the national economy.

Name: Sierra Leone Cholera Outbreak-2012
Summary__c: Since the first cases were reported in February, the latest cholera outbreak in Sierra Leone has caused an estimated 217 deaths and affected almost 12,000 people. The rate of new cases has accelerated rapidly since the beginning of August and spread to 10 of the country’s 13 districts. Hospitals and health centres in some districts lack clean water and stable power. The actual number of cholera cases may be higher than what has been reported because cases are often unreported or not treated by proper medical personnel.  There are a number of organizations currently responding in Sierra Leone but the majority are concentrated in the capital of Freetown.

Name: Horn of Africa Drought-2011
Summary__c: A drought that began in 2009 has resulted in massive crop failure, water scarcity, low food supplies, livestock deaths and the migration of residents from Ethiopia, Kenya, Djibouti, Tanzania and Somalia. A short rainy period at the end of 2011 improved the situation across much of the region, though drought conditions persist in some parts of Ethiopia and Kenya. Red Cross societies are largely ending food distributions and focusing their activities on reducing disaster risk, restoring livelihoods and promoting safe hygiene.

Name: Syria Crisis and Population Movement-2012
Summary__c: The conflict in Syria has been ongoing since March 2011; violence began after demonstrations demanding the departure of President Bashar al Assad. Conflict across the country has caused large-scale displacement and disintegration of infrastructure, leaving millions in need of food, health, shelter, and WASH assistance amid a dynamic conflict in which aid provision is highly problematic.

Name: Chile Earthquake-2010
Summary__c: On February 27, 2010, an earthquake of magnitude 8.8 occurred in Bío-Bío region in central Chile, 56 miles northeast of the city of Concepción. An ensuing tsunami affected the island of Juan Fernandez and communities along the coast in Bío-Bío region, inflicting loss of life and major damage to infrastructure.

Name: Japan Earthquake & Tsunami-2011
Summary__c: On March 11, a record 9.0 magnitude earthquake struck Sendai, Japan, generating a powerful 32-foot tsunami which caused widespread destruction to northern Japanese coastal areas and communities. Damage to a nuclear power plant caused the ongoing threat of radiation exposure.

Name: Haiti Earthquake-2010
Summary__c: On January 12, a magnitude 7 earthquake struck the Haitian coast 10 miles from the capital of Port-au-Prince, causing massive damage and generating a tsunami alert in Haiti and neighboring countries.

Name: Southeast Asia Typhoons-2009
Summary__c: Beginning in late September 2009, a series of typhoons hit Southeast Asia, causing floods and landslides affecting millions.  Typhoons Ketsana and Parma were particularly damaging to communities in the Philippines and Vietnam, although areas of Cambodia and Laos were also impacted.

Name: Mexico Hurricane Jimena-2009
Summary__c: Hurricane Jimena hit Mexico’s Baja California peninsula as a category two hurricane on September 3, affecting the state of Baja California Sur and later the state of Sonora. The hurricane affected 120,000 people, causing damage to homes, businesses, electricity infrastructure, and water and transportation systems.

Name: Palestine Gaza Crisis-2012
Summary__c: Starting on November 14, 2012, eight days of fighting across the border between Israel and Gaza resulted in 160 deaths and nearly 1,400 injuries in Gaza. Initial assessments in Gaza indicated that 137 houses were completely destroyed and 294 had been damaged. Airstrikes destroyed infrastructure and displaced approximately 12,000 people. Initial assessments also indicated an immediate need for relief supplies, medical supplies and ambulances.

Name: China Earthquake-2010
Summary__c: A 6.9 magnitude earthquake hit northwest China's Qinghai Province at 7:49am local time on April 14, 2010. Its epicenter was 31 miles from Jiegu Township, the government seat of the Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture of Yushu.  According to the U.S. Geological Survey, this is the strongest quake to hit the remote mountainous area since 1976.

Name: Argentina Floods-2013
Summary__c: On April 2, 2013 a severe storm caused heavy flooding in La Plata, the capital of Buenos Aires province in Argentina, bringing eleven inches of rain overnight. This was the highest level of rainfall the area experienced in a 24 hour period since 1980. Flood waters rose to over six feet in some areas causing destruction of homes and disruption to power and clean water supply. The floods affected over 350,000 people, caused 52 deaths and resulted in 3,000 people evacuating to shelters.

Name: Afghanistan Floods-2012
Summary__c: Melting snow and heavy rain have caused flash floods in the Sar-e-Pol and Jawzjan provinces of Afghanistan, damaging property and livelihoods.  Over five thousand homes have been damaged or destroyed, leaving many families unable to find alternative shelter. Water supply systems are inundated and local markets are difficult to access, making shelter, food, water and healthcare the top priorities for the response efforts.

Name: Haiti Hurricane Season-2008
Summary__c: Perparations for the 2008 hurrican season in the Caribbean.

Name: Caribbean Hurricane Tomas-2010
Summary__c: From October 30 to 31, Hurricane Tomas struck the Caribbean Islands of Barbados, Saint Lucia, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, causing landslides and damage to homes and infrastructure. Now downgraded in scale to a Tropical Storm, it is on course to strike Haiti within the next 48 hours, bringing heavy rains which are expected to severely affect the country.

Name: Philippines Floods-2012
Summary__c: Following the heaviest rains recorded in three years, the Philippines has experienced severe flooding that has impacted 2 million people.  Floods have damaged more than 14,000 homes and displaced approximately 500,000 people. The southwest monsoon was triggered by two storms, Typhoon Saola and Tropical Storm Haikui. More than 60 cities were immediately submerged in flood water. Continuous rain has affected a large majority of the country and some flood water is not expected to recede until February 2013. Thousands of people have sought refuge in evacuation centers, and are receiving basic provisions from the Philippine Red Cross.

Name: Mozambique Floods-2013
Summary__c: Heavy rains in January 2013 have caused flooding in Mozambique, destroying houses, schools, health centers and crops, forcing the affected populations to leave their homes in search of safer areas. These floods have affected more than 230,000 people and displaced more than 180,000 since the beginning of the rainy season in October 2012. The Ministry of Health confirmed a cholera outbreak in early February, with 317 cases and 2 deaths reported. The threat of more rain from an approaching storm could worsen flooding and cause further displacement and destruction.

Name: Kenya Floods-2013
Summary__c: Seasonal rains starting in March 2013 have caused severe flooding and landslides in Kenya, destroying houses, crops and vital infrastructure, forcing affected populations to leave their homes in search of safer areas. Flooding has displaced 10,000 households, caused 39 deaths and destroyed 640 households completely. Rains are forecasted to continue into the month of June and could worsen flooding and cause further displacement and destruction.  Immediate needs include search and rescue services, safe shelter, access to water and improved sanitation, health and hygiene education, and grants to enable affected populations to purchase the supplies they need in areas where markets are functioning.

Name: Philippines Typhoons-2011
Summary__c: Two typhoons have hit the Philippines within a five-day span. Typhoon Nesat struck September 27 with strong gusts and heavy rains, triggering floods and widespread damage across the entire island of Luzon. Before the country could recover, another less powerful storm, Typhoon Nalgae, struck on October 1, following the same route, adding to flooding and isolating communities.

Name: North Africa & Middle East Civil Unrest-2011
Summary__c: A year after violence began between the Syrian government and protestors demanding political reform, the humanitarian situation in Syria has worsened. Thousands of people are trapped in their homes, are caught in open conflict or are fleeing to escape the fighting. Food and water supplies are running low in some areas and medical needs are urgent. The Syrian Arab Red Crescent has been assisting those in need since the violence began. It is the only humanitarian organization on the ground in many parts of the country and is working hard to ensure that its neutrality and impartiality is understood by all sides. The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has called for a daily two-hour cease-fire so that the Syrian Arab Red Crescent can deliver medical assistance and aid to the worst-affected areas.  The ICRC and Red Crescent have been granted very little access by the Syrian government to enter the severely-hit Baba Amr neighborhood of Homs. The UN reports that more than 9,000 people have been killed during the conflict, including more than 600 children. The UN and other organizations have called for immediate humanitarian action.

Name: Paraguay Dengue Epidemic-2011
Summary__c: Paraguay Dengue Epidemic

Name: Belize Hurricane Richard-2010
Summary__c: On October 24, Hurricane Richard hit Belize with sustained winds of 90 mph, tracking directly across the cities of Belmopan and Belize City. It damaged over 800 homes and was particularly destructive to local agriculture.

Name: Namibia Floods-2011
Summary__c: Months of rain have caused large-scale flooding in northern Namibia, displacing thousands of people and destroying homes, crops, roads and other infrastructure. The Namibian government and the Namibia Red Cross Society are responding to the floods. The government has declared a state of national emergency and has reported that more than 228,500 people are affected and 60,000 are displaced, with 65 deaths due to the flooding. The UN reports there are approximately 78 relocation centers housing an estimated 15,000 people in the six affected regions. The Namibia Red Cross Society reports that houses, roads, bridges, businesses, crops and other infrastructure have been destroyed in the affected regions of Caprivi, Ohangwena, Oshana, Oshikoto, Kavango and Omusati. Some communities are inaccessible and cut off from assistance.

Name: Afghanistan Conflict-2001
Summary__c: Afghanistan Conflict-2001

Name: Hurricane Sandy-2012
Summary__c: Hurricane Sandy began as a tropical storm in the western Caribbean in October 2012 and intensified into a hurricane before making landfall over south-eastern Jamaica. It then moved over Cuba, affecting Haiti and the Dominican Republic as well, before making landfall in the U.S.

Name: India Floods-2009
Summary__c: Since September 29, the heaviest rains in more than a century have inundated parts of Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka states in southern India. The Krishna River and its tributaries has flooded surrounding villages, killing 384 people, displacing 674,500 and affecting more than 4.1 million .

Name: Panama Floods-2010
Summary__c: Continuous rains have fallen across Panama since early November, causing two deaths and affecting over 24,000 people in eight provinces. Overflowing rivers have caused severe floods over wide areas, while landslides have affected homes and cut off many communities.

Name: Solomon Islands Storm-2003
Summary__c: Solomon Islands Storm-2003

Name: Bolivia Floods-2011
Summary__c: Disruptions in weather patterns due to the La Niña effect have resulted in heavy rains in Bolivia, causing floods and mudslides affecting 88,000 people in 30% of the country’s municipalities. The Bolivian government estimates 7,400 acres of food crops have been lost.  Access to the affected areas is difficult due to damaged roads and bridges. Affected families are sheltering in camps and evacuation centers.  Authorities note the need for longer-term shelter solutions is becoming urgent, particularly in La Paz city, where there are challenges in locating land for transitional housing for families whose homes were destroyed by landslides.

Name: Mongolia Severe Winter-2010
Summary__c: More than ninety percent of Mongolia is experiencing severe winter conditions compounded by dzud, a phenomenon resulting from continuous heavy snowfall combined with extreme cold and preceded by dry summers, resulting in the insufficient production of grazing pastures. Herding is the main livelihood for 80 percent of Mongolia’s rural community. The dzud has had a devastating effect on the livelihood of herders by causing a serious loss of livestock, their primary source of income and food.

Name: Philippines Typhoon Megi-2010
Summary__c: Typhoon Megi battered the Philippines on October 18, when it made landfall in the north of the country as a Category 5 typhoon with 140 mph winds and heavy rains.  While evacuation efforts saved many lives, the typhoon caused significant damage to homes, livelihoods and infrastructure.

Name: Indonesia Floods-2016
Summary__c: Heavy rains that have been pounding the Island of Sumatra, Indonesia, since 7 February, have caused signficant floods and landslides, killing at least 5 people, damaging more than 7,100 houses and displacing or isolating at least 12,000 families. As well as causing a substantial humanitarian impact, the floods have rendered some villages inaccesible, due to damaged bridges or blocked roads, and submerged public facilities including health centres and schools. Based on preliminary information, some 14,400 families (around 55,900 people) have been affected across 5 provinces.

Name: Malawi Food Insecurity-2012
Summary__c: As a result of low food production in some districts and an increasing economic crisis, Malawi is facing a critical food shortage, affecting an estimated 1.9 million people. The food shortage is concentrated in central and southern Malawi, affecting approximately 11% of the total population and over 50% of the population in two southern districts, Nsanje and Chikhwawa. Heavy rains and flooding in the spring, followed by prolonged dry spells resulted in poor harvests this fall. The next harvest season is not expected until March 2013.  The current situation is exacerbated by fuel shortages, rising food prices, and rapid inflation which occurred earlier this year.

Name: China Winter Storms-2008
Summary__c: A series of winter storm events affected large portions of southern and central China starting on 25 January 2008 until 6 February 2008. The systems affected most of the area with heavy snows, ice and cold temperatures causing extensive damage and transportation disruption for several thousand travelers. It became China's worst winter weather in half a century.

Name: Mexico Floods-2010
Summary__c: The 2010 hurricane season has significantly impacted Mexico. Record high seasonal rains combined with two major storms in the past month have generated extensive flooding in Mexico’s southern states, affecting an estimated 500,000 people. Hurricane Karl hit on September 17, followed by Tropical Storm Matthew on September 26.

Name: Bangladesh Floods-2011
Summary__c: Two months of continuous torrential rains coupled with a monsoonal depression in the Bay of Bengal has caused flooding that has affected more than 1.5 million people in 18 districts in Bangladesh.

Name: West Africa Population Movement-2010
Summary__c: Political turmoil following December’s presidential elections in Cote d’Ivoire has caused armed clashes and prompted significant internal and cross border population movements into neighboring countries. Liberia has been particularly impacted with thousands of Ivorians crossing its border, placing burdens on communities. Up to one million people have been internally displaced in Cote d’Ivoire, and more than 100,000 have crossed into Liberia. Many of the displaced are staying with host families.

Name: Panama Floods-2012
Summary__c: On Sunday, November 25, 2012 heavy rains over the western part of Panama triggered floods and landslides causing at least five deaths and affecting over 5,000 people. Landslides have also caused a disruption of economic activities and hampered access to some communities. Figures of people who have died and been affected are likely to increase as more isolated communities have not yet been reached. Preliminary reports indicate that over 1,000 houses were damaged. The situation is likely to worsen as overflow of rivers and continued threat of landslides restrict access to flooded communities, particularly in the mountainous areas.

Name: Samoa Islands Tsunami-2009
Summary__c: On September 29, an earthquake of magnitude 8.0 occurred in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of American Samoa, causing a destructive tsunami wave that struck American Samoa, Samoa and the island of Niuatoputapu in Tonga. Samoan reports state the wave that hit in Apia, Samoa was two feet while the second, larger wave in Pago Pago, American Samoa, was six feet.

Name: Timor-Leste Floods-2006
Summary__c: Severe flooding affected the East Timor region.

Name: Syria Drought-2009
Summary__c: Syria has experienced a drought since 2006, but conditions have worsened in the last eight months as high temperatures and low rainfall destroyed much of the seasonal crop of grain. Currently 1.3 million people in eastern Syria are affected, and an estimated 800,000 have lost most of their income and are facing extreme hardship. These conditions have triggered a substantial increase in the rate of migration from villages in the affected areas to urban centers during the past year.  Urgent humanitarian action is needed to enable residents of eastern Syria to remain in their homes and avoid further migration to Damascus and other cities.

Name: Central America Floods-2011
Summary__c: Since the beginning of October, heavy rains associated with a tropical depression have caused flooding and landslides throughout Central America—most severely in Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Nicaragua—resulting in more than 100 deaths and affecting more than 630,000 people.

Name: Indonesia West Sumatra Earthquake-2009
Summary__c: Over a 48-hour period, two earthquakes struck the west coast of the island of Sumatra in Indonesia. On September 29 a magnitude 7.6 earthquake struck Padang, and on October 1 a magnitude 6.8 earthquake struck Jambi.  The government of Indonesia reports 1,195 deaths as a result of the two earthquakes.

Name: Horn of Africa Food Insecurity Crisis-2008
Bangladesh Floods-2012
Summary__c: While still responding to the heavy rains from earlier this year that caused floods and landslides in ten districts, Bangladesh was struck by a fast moving tropical storm that caused damage to over 27,000 homes in three districts on the coast. Due to the quick onset of the storm, as meteorological agencies weren’t able to give much advanced warning, the fishing community was particularly affected by being caught out on the water. Organizations on the ground in Bangladesh are coordinating response activities with the government and through the Humanitarian Coordination Task Team (HCTT).

Name: Paraguay Fire-2004
Summary__c: More than 300 people were killed in a supermarket fire on the outskirts of the Paraguayan capital, Asunción. The supermarket doors were locked, trapping victims inside the building.

Name: Sahel Food Crisis-2012
Summary__c: More than 11 million people in the Sahel region of West Africa, which includes Burkina Faso, Chad, Mali, Mauritania, Niger and some parts of Senegal, face severe food shortages due to crop failure caused by erratic rainfall and drought. This will worsen the chronic risk of food insecurity and malnutrition many families in the region already face. The Sahel region will run out of food stocks earlier than usual and already high food prices are expected to increase, which will limit families’ ability to purchase additional food at markets. Immediate priority needs are for food assistance, nutritional supplements and agriculture support. In several regions in Chad, Mauritania, Niger and Senegal, child malnutrition rates are already above the emergency threshold of 15 percent. Without immediate action, the situation is predicted to worsen. The population’s ability to obtain food has also been impacted by an increase in crime and insecurity due to armed groups in Chad, Mali, Mauritania and Niger.

Name: Colombia Floods-2011
Summary__c: Colombia has been experiencing a heavier than normal rainy season since September. Many communities are affected and are relying on government authorities and the Colombian Red Cross for basic assistance. The UN reports that 410,000 people are affected across more than 80 percent of the country. More than 100 people have died and 62,300 homes have been damaged. The most critical needs identified by the Red Cross are for food, temporary shelters, tarps, hygiene items as well as water and sanitation services. In the departments of Cesar, Chocó and Córdoba y Norte de Santander, the combination of heavy rain and ongoing armed conflict have created even greater humanitarian needs.

Name: Kenya Drought-2009
Summary__c: In Kenya, the cumulative effects of three consecutive failed rainy seasons and the 2008 post election violence have crippled food production, creating a 40% shortfall in the 2009 national grain harvest.  In northern and eastern Kenya, an estimated 3.8 million pastoralists and marginal farmers require urgent food assistance. Recently, rain has brought some relief to drought-stricken areas but it will be months before the harvest comes.

Name: El Salvador Hurricane Stan & Volcano Eruption-2005
Vietnam Floods-2011
Summary__c: According to the Vietnam government’s flood control agency, a total of 140,000 households (approximately 590,000 people) have been affected by the floods.  At least 73 people are dead, more than 91,400 houses are damaged and 24,000 acres of rice paddies destroyed. Government authorities have opened shelters and health stations to support those in need, but food supplies are low and people continue to face difficulties in everyday living. Assessments performed by the Vietnam Red Cross and other agencies indicate that the greatest needs are for food, tarps, blankets, mosquito nets, safe water, hygiene and health promotion activities. According to the Mekong River Commission, floodwaters are forecasted to remain high at least until mid-November.

Name: Vietnam Floods-2010
Summary__c: Since October 1, torrential rains have caused rivers and dams to overflow, inundating five provinces in Central Vietnam.  To date, more than 100 people are reported dead and another 660,000 affected in the worst flooding in the country in 20 years.

Name: Middle East Population Displaced from Iraq-2007
Pakistan Floods-2011
Summary__c: Since the beginning of August, monsoon rains have caused widespread flooding in southern Pakistan and isolated floods and landslides across the north of the country, affecting 5 million people.

Name: Haiti Floods-2009
Summary__c: On October 20, heavy rains triggered flooding in Haiti’s Carrefour department, located west of the capital of Port-au-Prince. The rains caused both flash flooding as well as left standing water, damaging the homes and belongings of 500 families.

Name: Haiti & Dominican Republic Cholera Outbreak-2010
Summary__c: Since October, a severe cholera outbreak has spread from the Artibonite River to all departments in Haiti. Cholera is a highly contagious illness, especially in situations with poor sanitation, a lack of clean water and crowded living conditions. It causes severe diarrhea and dehydration and can kill within 24 hours if not treated.

Name: Philippines Typhoon Washi-2011
Summary__c: Typhoon Washi hit the southern Philippines on December 17, bringing heavy rains and strong winds which resulted in massive flooding and widespread damage in the Northern Mindanao area.  According to government reports, the number of dead and missing is now more than 1,000. More than 10,000 homes were damaged or destroyed, displacing 284,600 people. More than 42,700 people are in 63 evacuation centers and another 241,800 people are staying with relatives or in makeshift structures.

Name: Colombia Volcano-2016
Summary__c: A series of small explosions occurred at the volcano on March 10. The Manizales volcano observatory recorded a pulse in tremor and reported an ash plume that rose 1300 m above the summit.

Name: Iraq Dam-2016
Summary__c: The ongoing conflict between Iraqi security forces and ISIS has caused engineers at the Mosul Dam in Northern Iraq to flee, leaving the structure largely unattended. Poor construction techniques and limited engineering oversight has raised the risk of a partial or complete breach, leading to flood waters moving downstream. There is the potential that such flooding could send unexploded ordinance towards populated areas.

Name: Micronesia and Marshall Islands Drought-2016
Summary__c: As a result of the El Niño phenomenon, much of the Pacific region is experiencing weather extremes. Micronesia and the Marshall Islands have declared states of emergency for drought conditions.

Name: Paraguay Floods-2015
Summary__c: Flash floods were reported in northern Paraguay in December, affecting up to 19,750 people. The situation has since escalated, affecting a majority of the country.

Name: Myanmar Earthquake-2016
Summary__c: An earthquake of magnitude 6.9 struck mid-eastern Myanmar on 13 April at 13.55 UTC. The epicentre was located approx. 74 km south-east of Mawlaik city (Myanmar/Burma). The earthquake was also felt across India and Bangladesh; USGS PAGER estimated that 745 000 people were exposed to "Strong" and 5,877,000 people to "Moderate" shaking. In Myanmar/Burma, local media report several homes damaged, as of 14 April.

Name: Costa Rica Population Movement-2015
Summary__c: Beginning in November 2015, increasing number of Cuban migrants are arriving at the Paso Canoas border crossing between Panama and Costa Rica.

Name: Argentina Floods-2016
Summary__c: More than 20,000 people were displaced by the end of December due to floods caused by the rise of the Uruguay, Paraná, and Paraguay rivers, brought on by heavy rainfall in the provinces of Entre Ríos, Corrientes, Formosa, Chaco y Santa Fe. The impact on the agricultural sector is expected to be severe.

Name: Guatemala Landslides-2015
Summary__c: On October 3, a major landslide outside of the village left a village of over 100 houses buried. So far, 161 people have been found dead, with 300 people still missing. GRC is working closely with the government to respond with approx 200 responders. GRC has requested DREF funds to cover operational costs but doubtful that there will be a request for an emergency appeal or bilateral support.

Name: Somalia Droughts-2016
Summary__c: Low rain totals in 2015 have carried over into 2016, increasing the number of acutely food insecure people.

Name: Fiji Tropical Cyclone Zena-2016
Summary__c: A new tropical cyclone is threating Fiji less than two months after Severe Tropical Cyclone Winston lashed with a deadly impact. According to projections by the Fiji Metrological Service, TC Zena – a Category 3 cyclone – will have average winds of 100 kph and gusts of 150 kph. The cyclone is located about 630 km west of Nadi and is moving eastsoutheast at 35 kph.

Name: Canada Wildfires-2016
Summary__c: The 2016 Fort McMurray wildfire began on May 1, 2016, southwest of the urban service area of Fort McMurray in the Regional Municipality of Wood Buffalo, Alberta. It has since spread through the town, forcing the largest evacuation of residents in Alberta's history and the destruction of thousands of homes. An unusually warm May temperature of 32 °C (90 °F), and low humidity at 15%, have contributed to the fire's growth. It has been reported that 88,000 people were successfully evacuated, with no reported fatalities or injuries.

Name: Burundi Complex Emergency-2015
Summary__c: The current rainy season has been causing severe damages to housing due the El Niño climate event since November 2015, and is expected to continue until May 2016. Until mid-January 2016, heavy rains and floods resulted in the damage and/or the destruction of 5,068 houses in Burundi, affecting 30,408 persons who are in need of assistance in shelter/NFI, based on assessments conducted by the authorities with support from the Burundian Red Cross.

Name: TEST-ENZ-Disaster W/o RFA-2016-2016
Summary__c: test

Name: Japan Earthquakes-2016
Summary__c: Two major earthquakes that have struck the Kyushu island of Japan – within a span of two days – have left at least 32 people dead, more than 2,000 injured and dozens missing. The first earthquake, of magnitude 6.5, struck on Thursday, 14 April 21:26 local time, resulting in at least nine people dead and 800 injured. According to the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA), the epicentre of the quake was in the Kumamoto Prefecture with a depth of 11 kilometres.

Name: Tanzania Population Movement-2015
Summary__c: As a result of political violence in Burundi that began in April of 2015, hundreds of thousands have fled to neighboring countries. Tanzania has received most of the refugees and is sheltering them in several camps.

Name: India Typhoon Phailin-2013
Summary__c: Cyclone Phailin made landfall along India’s eastern coast on October 12, 2013. Over 1.1 million residents in the region were evacuated before the storm hit. Some 60,000 people were left homeless after the storm hit 14,000 villages mainly in coastal districts. An estimated 13.23 million people were affected; 47 people were found dead. As emergency teams began assessing damage from the country’s biggest cyclone in 14 years, a massive relief effort went into full swing to distribute food to an estimated one million evacuees, clear roads and help the injured. More than 950,000 houses were damaged, including 540,000 in the cyclone and 407,000 in the subsequent floods.

Name: Sri Lanka Flood and Landslides-2016
Summary__c: A tropical depression in the Bay of Bengal brought heavy rains across the country, triggering floods and landslides that have affected thousands of lives and livelihoods, and caused widespread property damage. Initial reports indicated 22 out of Sri Lanka’s 25 districts are reported to be affected, among them Colombo, Gampaha, Kegalle, Kurunegala and Puttalam. IFRC launched Emergency Appeal for $3.6M.

Name: Timor Leste Drought 2016-2016
Summary__c: Due to the current El Niño effect, Timor Leste's annual rainy/wet season (which normally lasts from December to March) has been low - and delayed in some areas - leading to drought conditions in many parts of the country. A rapid assessment conducted by the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries (MAF) estimates that at least 120,000 people have been severely affected across five districts (Baucau, Covalima, Lautem, Oecusse and Viqueque), with 45.9 per cent of households across the country likely to experience food insecurity from April to June.The IFRC have issued a $800,000 appeal.

Name: Uganda Population Movement-2013
Summary__c: The escalating violence in the Republic of South Sudan has provoked a mass population displacement within South Sudan and into neighboring countries. Uganda has taken the bulk of refugees who have continued to cross the borders since the beginning of the conflict in mid-December 2013. More than 60,000 South Sudanese refugees have crossed into Uganda, and these numbers are expected to increase as the conflict continues between the Government of South Sudan and the opposition, despite the Peace Agreement signed by both parties in January 2014. The increasing number of refugees means that tens of thousands of people in Uganda are in dire need of emergency medical care, shelter, food, water, and adequate sanitation facilities.

Name: Bangladesh Cyclone Roanu 2016-2016
Summary__c: Cyclone Roanu hit Bangladesh on Saturday, May 21, 2016. More than 83,000 houses were damaged or destroyed and 153,000 households have been affected by the storm. The main needs are clean water, food and shelter. The BRCS have requested a DREF which will be issued for $250,000 and a $2M appeal has been issued.

Name: Myanmar Floods-2015
Summary__c:
Since mid-July 2015, floods and landslides in several parts of Myanmar have resulted in widespread loss of life, injuries, displacement of people from their homes, damage to houses, agriculture and livelihoods. The President of Myanmar issued a statement declaring natural disaster zones in Chin and Rakhine states, and in the Sagaing and Magway regions. The government indicated that it would accept international assistance.

Map of flood affected areas
OCHA Report - 8/21

Name: Pakistan Monsoon Floods-2010
Summary__c: In July 2010, heavy monsoon rains swept through large areas of Pakistan, affecting 18 million people and causing unprecedented floods that submerged homes, roads, bridges and cropland in more than 70% of the country.  The flooding led to widespread displacement of people, destruction of communities and damage to infrastructure.

Name: Morocco Cold Wave-2016
Summary__c: A cold wave has affected Morocco on Saturday 27 February, 2016, caused by a polar air mass flow passing from the North Pole to Europe and North Africa, and has generated westerly winds that has brought extreme and exceptionally low temperatures. This wave of frost and snow has caused economic losses and isolated several areas in Morocco. Furthermore, electricity was interrupted and some houses suffered structural damages and water supply was interrupted in many regions due to the freezing temperatures.

Name: Rwanda Population Movement-2015
Summary__c: Since early April 2015, over 70,000 Burundi nationals have sought refuge in Rwanda due to pre-election tension and violence. Bujumbura currently remains particularly unstable, and refugees are crossing into Rwanda through 25 border entry points across 10 districts along the Burundi-Rwanda border, in the south east of the country.

Name: Iraq Population Movement-2014
Summary__c: In early June, the security situation in northern regions of Iraq deteriorated as fighting between the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) and the Iraqi government reached major cities. Mosul, the second largest city in Iraq, fell under the control of ISIS on June 10, followed by most of the surrounding Ninewah province. Security conditions have also worsened in Salah al-Din and Diyala provinces. The recent violence has displaced more than 650,000 people to the Kurdistan Region of Iraq. If the situation continues to deteriorate, humanitarian organizations expect significant additional displacements. This rapid population movement adds to the approximate 550,000 people displaced since January by a surge of violence in central and northern Iraq, and the more than 200,000 refugees from the Syria crisis currently residing in Iraq. Overall, an estimated 1.5 million people, including displaced persons, host communities and communities under siege are in need of humanitarian assistance in Iraq, a 300 percent increase from February. Humanitarian actors are mobilizing all resources available to scale up emergency operations across Iraq. Priority humanitarian needs are food, water and fuel. Protection and the risk of disease outbreak are also concerns, primarily for the hundreds of thousands displaced during the June offensive. Host communities are being increasingly stretched, as the conflict in neighboring Syria has also led to a large influx of refugees, mostly into the Kurdistan region.

Name: Mexico Hurricane Patricia-2015
Summary__c:
A potentially catastrophic landfall is expected Friday evening as a very powerful and dangerous Hurricane Patricia moves towards Mexico's Pacific coast. Hurricane Patricia became the most powerful tropical cyclone ever measured in the Western Hemisphere on Friday morning as its maximum sustained winds reached an unprecedented 200 mph (320 kph).

The hurricane is forecast to make landfall in the Mexican state of Jalisco Friday evening as a catastrophic Category 5 hurricane capable of causing widespread destruction. Residents and authorities in Mexico are rushing to prepare for what will likely be the strongest hurricane to ever make landfall on that country's Pacific coastline.

Name: Philippines Typhoon Koppu-2015
Summary__c:
Typhoon Koppu (locally known as Lando) made landfall over the town of Casiguran, Aurora province (around to 350 km northeast of Manila), on Sunday 18 October 2015 as an equivalent of a category 3 cyclone, packing maximum sustained winds of 185 km/h near the centre and gusts of up to 220 km/h. After landfall, the typhoon skirted the northern part of Luzon Island, moving at a slow speed of 5 kph and bringing heavy rains within its 600-kilometre diameter.

Situation Update
  • According to the latest update released by National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (NDRRMC), Koppu left 47 people dead, 83 injured and four missing.
  • In all, a total of 2,733,294 people (630,602 families) were affected across seven regions.
  • Some 89,900 people remain in 311 evacuation centres.
  • Koppu has been described as the most destructive storm to hit Philippines in 2015, with the cost of damage wrought on agriculture and infrastructure estimated at PHP 9.8 billion (CHF 206 million); a total of 103,447 houses were damaged; 15,289 totally and 88,158 partially with 803 schools damaged – 249 totally and 554 partially.

Action by PRC:
  • PRC is in full response mode, and its chapters continue to deliver assistance to affected people. Initial assistance was on saving lives, and in that regard the National Society rescued 728 people who had been trapped by floodwater.
  • As of Sunday 25 October 2015 evening, PRC had provided:
    • Psychosocial support to 10,075 people
    • 10,793 people with hot, ready-to-eat, meals
    • 5,514 families with food packs comprising of rice, noodles and canned items
    • 2,755 families with sleeping items (sleeping mats and blankets)
    • 959 families with mosquito nets
    • 634 families with jerry cans
    • 436 families with tarpaulins
  • Distributions continue, with a substantial part of them covered by the DREF allocation approved on 20 October.
 
IFRC support:
  • IFRC continues to work with PRC on the response at the National Society’s headquarters level, including in moving forward the DREF-supported action; however, the three IFRC delegates who had been deployed to support the National Society in the immediate response, communications and rapid assessments have returned to their respective duty stations as the response is considered within the capacity of PRC chapters to handle.
  • The IFRC Country Delegation is representing the IFRC system (Secretariat and National Societies) in NDRRMC and HCT meetings, together with relevant PRC staff.
 
Looking ahead:
  • Following an analysis of funding scenarios, an international appeal will not be launched for this response. Instead, IFRC will support in promoting PRC’s domestic appeal for partners to support directly to the National Society.

Name: Vietnam Drought-2016
Summary__c: Drought and saltwater intrusion in Vietnam’s southern and central regions will persist through April. Temperatures in the central and southern Vietnam in April and May will be around one degree Celsius higher than the average in recent years. Nearly half of the 2.2 million hectares (5.4 million acres) of arable land in the Mekong Delta had been attacked by saltwater and hundreds of thousands of locals are suffering from water scarcity.

Name: Senegal Food Insecurity-2015
Summary__c: In the Sahel, a number of countries are being affected by food insecurity, including Gambia, Guinea Bissau, Mauritania and Senegal. Over 3.8 million people are food insecure, including 1,040,000 in PIC Phase 3 crisis due to erratic rains in 2014.

Name: Haiti & Dominican Republic Population Movement-2015
Summary__c: Thousands of people of Haitian descent face possible deportation from DR.

Name: Peru Cold Front-2015
Summary__c: Since May 2015, a meteorological phenomenon causing low temperatures, heavy snowfall and frost has affected the Andead regions located about 3,500 meters; temperatures have dropped below 0 Celsius and there have been snowstorms and hail. An initial declaration of 45-day state of emergency on 19 July 2015, for 10 districts and provinces. On 5 August, the government escalated its original declaration of a state of emergency nationwide.

Name: Bangladesh Cyclone Komen-2015
Summary__c: The monsoon depression over the northeast Bay of Bengal and the Bangladesh coast intensified into Cyclone Komen on Wednesday, 29 July 2015, causing further downpours in regions already affected by recent storms, flash floods and landslides which had started at the end of June 2015. Since mid-July, IFRC has been monitoring the situation and working closely with BDRCS in responding to the immediate needs of the affected communities. Cyclone Komen made landfall along the coast of south-eastern Bangladesh between the Hatiya and Sandwip islands on 30 July, weakening as it moved slightly towards the northeast. Cox’s Bazar, Chittagong, Bandarban, Noakhali, Feni and Bhola1 districts were significantly affected. At least 7 people (2 of them children) were reported dead, 38 missing, and a number injured due to the cyclone. Thousands of houses were flattened and trees uprooted. Many houses went under water, power supplies were disrupted, and communication systems ceased to operate in some places. Crops were damaged and shrimp projects flooded.

Name: Rwanda Floods-2016
Summary__c: At least 49 people have been killed after heavy rain caused widespread flooding across parts of Rwanda. The Northern Province was worst affected and suffered the highest death toll.

Name: Sudan Population Movement-2015
Summary__c: Clashes between Government forces and armed movements in Jebel Marra area and North Darfur State displace an estimated 41,000 people in North Darfur and Central Darfur, and tribal clashes reportedly displace more than 100,000 people around Mellit and in East Darfur. With clashes in Darfur now in their 12th year, an estimated 3.7 million people in Darfur are in need of humanitarian assistance.Of these, 1.2 million are are also in a state of critical food insecurity.

Name: Micronesia Cyclone Maysak-2015
Summary__c: Typhoon Maysak moved through the Federated States of Micronesia beginning on the 29 of March as a super typhoon, bringing damaging winds and torrential rainfall to the archipelago that has caused widespread damage to houses, infrastructure, crops and water sources. In Chuuk state, five deaths have been confirmed more than 6,000 people were displaced in shelters or living with relatives. In Yap state, where the storm made landfall, the majority of homes were destroyed and there is widespread damage to crops and infrastructure as well as possible contamination of food and water sources.  Assessments are ongoing, but priority needs include food and essential household items, safe water, emergency shelter, health and hygiene.

Name: Kenya Floods-2016
Summary__c: Heavy rain and flooding in the Kenyan capital city of Nairobi are being blamed for a building collapse that has killed at least 20 people.

Name: Yemen Conflict-2015
Summary__c: The violence in Yemen has escalated rapidly in the last month; on 26 March, a military coalition known as "Operation Decisive Storm" began launching air strikes in the country. Aside from these clashes, bombings and bouts of fighting have continued and, in several governorates, worsened. The political situation also remains extremely volatile, with many government positions now disputed or unoccupied.

Name: Kazakhstan Flash Floods-2015
Summary__c: A sudden rise of temperature in central and eastern Kazakhstan resulted in the fast melting of snow that caused floods on 8-9 April 2015. A state of emergency was declared in the regions of Akmola, Karaganda and Pavlodar, situation in the eastern and northern parts of Kazakhstan.  More than 50 settlements were affected, and more than 12,000 people were evacuated. Transportation infrastructure and bridge have also been destroyed, livestock killed and the electricty and water supplies have been disrupted.

Name: Rwanda Floods-2015
Summary__c: On April 3, 2015 the Nyamasheke and Rubavu district located in the Western Province of Rwanda experienced heavy rainfall, which resulted in flooding and landslides. According to preliminary assessments by Rwanda Red Cross, it is estimated that 3,425 people have been affected and are being accommodated in nearby communities. Crops and water supple and sanitation infrastructures have also been flooded.

Name: Nepal Earthquake-2015
Summary__c:
A powerful 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck Nepal on April 25, 2015 at midday local time. The epicenter was located in Lamjung District, northwest of Kathmandu and south of the China border. Dozens of aftershocks followed.  Two weeks later, on May 12, a 7.3 magnitude earthquake struck Dolakha District, northeast of Kathmandu.  An estimated 8 million people (nearly a third of Nepal's population) was affected across 31 districts in Nepal's West and Central Regions. More than 8,800 people died, and another 100,000 were injured. More than 800,000 houses were destroyed or damaged by the quakes, forcing nearly 3 million people out of their homes and into makeshift shelters.

Maps:
Nepal Earthquake USGS – American Red Cross – April 25, 2015
Nepal Earthquake USGS – SIMS – May 12, 2015

Name: Paraguay Severe Local Storms-2015
Summary__c: On April 4, 2015 a severe storm hit several towns in Concepcion in northern Paraguay, affecting houses, crops and farm animals. Authorities estimate that 5,000 people were affected and have begun the response by providing roofing material, food and medical attention.

Name: Panama Fire-2015
Summary__c: On Wednesday June 3, 2015, a large fire almost entirely destroyed the indigenous community of Aguas Claras in the Comarca Guna de Magundandi. Approximately 800 people have been affected by the fire, which completely destroyed 160 houses and livelihood in the community.

Name: Caribbean Tropical Storm Danny-2015
Summary__c: Tropical Cyclone Danny became the first hurricane of the Atlantic Hurricane Season on August 20.Storm weakened to Category 2 on Friday and down to a Tropical Depression on Monday as it passed over Leeward Islands. Warnings were issued by Antigua and Barbuda Meteorological Services for Anguilla, Antigua and Barbuda, Montserrat and St Kitts/Nevis.

Name: Europe Population Movement-2015
Summary__c: Greece has experienced a dramatic increase in migrant arrivals at sea in 2015, with numbers of arrivals surpassing those of Italy in recent weeks. The main groups of migrants are arriving via Greece's sea borders with Turkey, with six islands most seriously impacted by this increase - Chios, Crete, Kos, Lesbos, Rhodes, and Samos. Authorities have reported a three-fold increase of arrivals for the same period in 2014, and the numbers in the past weeks continue to increase dramatically. According to available data, more than 90% are coming from countries experiencing war and conflict, principally Syria, Afghanistan, Iraq and Somalia.

Name: Dominica Tropical Storm Erika-2015
Summary__c: The island of Dominica sustained significant damage due to the passage of Tropical Storm Erika on August 28. A band of torrential rain caused by the storm resulted in 6-8 inches of rainfall in less than 12 hours and triggered massive flooding and several landslides.

Name: Standard Disaster
Summary__c: Standard Disaster

Name: West Africa Ebola Virus Outbreak-2014
Summary__c: The current outbreak of Ebola in West Africa is considered one of the largest, most complex and most severe outbreaks in recorded history, according to the UN World Health Organization (WHO). This epidemic is exceptionally large, not principally because of the biological characteristics of the virus, but because of insufficient control efforts used to halt the spread of infection and stigma surrounding the disease, which has discouraged people from interacting with the healthcare system.

Name: Paraguay Drought-2013
Summary__c: Drought conditions have impacted the Chaco region of Paraguay since early May, 2013. In September the Government of Paraguay declared a state of emergency in Chaco. The drought is affecting an estimated 15,000 families in 246 communities. Access to safe water is limited and crop, livestock and dairy production has decreased. Some of the affected communities are still recovering from damaged infrastructure due to flooding last year. Frost in July and August caused additional losses in agricultural production. Assessments indicate an immediate need for food, clean water and repair of water catchments systems.

Name: Zimbabwe Food Insecurity-2013
Summary__c: Zimbabwe is experiencing chronic and declining food security. Since March 2013 the number of people affected has increased 32 percent from 1.6 million to 2.2 million. The late onset of rainfall followed by prolonged dry spells, coupled with households’ limited access to seeds for planting, has worsened the food security situation. The government has started importing maize from South Africa and Zambia to guarantee food reserves in the country. Supply of grain is low throughout the country, with higher prices in rural areas.

Name: Philippines Typhoon Haiyan-2013
Summary__c:
• Typhoon Haiyan, locally known as Yolanda, made initial landfall in Eastern Samar, Philippines on November 8, 2013. The storm tracked across the Visayas region, bringing high winds, torrential rain and storm surge, impacting an estimated 16 million people.  
  • According to the latest Philippine government estimates, Typhoon Haiyan affected an estimated 16.1 million people, an increase from the previous estimate of 14.1 million. This includes 4.1 million people who remain displaced from their homes. 
  • Approximately 1.1 million houses were damaged during the typhoon.

Name: Ukraine Civil Unrest-2013
Summary__c: Demonstrations began in Kiev, Ukraine in November 2013 in protest of the government’s decision not to sign a trade agreement with the European Union. These demonstrations culminated in an unprecedented level of violence in Kiev in mid-February, after which the president vacated his post and an interim replacement government was approved by parliament. Since the change in government, protests in opposition to the new government have emerged and escalated, primarily in southern and eastern Ukraine. On March 16, 2014, the result of the referendum organized in Crimea around the question of independence from Ukraine was in favor of full independence of Crimea and integration into the Russian Federation. The results of the referendum and the subsequent integration of Crimea into the Russian Federation have not been recognized by any country, including Ukraine. This situation in southern and eastern Ukraine continues to be volatile, with the possibility of further escalation of violence, and may lead to unpredictable consequences for the civilian population during its movement in search of safety. There is no reliable data on the actual number of people displaced.

Name: Canada: Alberta Floods-2013
Summary__c: In June, 2013 the worst floods on record hit southern Alberta displacing over 100,000 people and killing four people. As many as 27 local states of emergency were declared throughout the province and 28 emergency operations centers were activated as water levels increased and evacuations occurred. Flooding caused major transportation and telecommunication infrastructure damage, power outages and water contamination. An estimated $6 billion in damages occurred. Currently, hundreds of families and individuals are still displaced, waiting for home repairs or affordable accommodation which is in short supply in flood-affected areas. Hundreds more are still struggling to rebuild, renovate or repair their houses, are faced with dwindling financial resources, or feel frustrated by payouts from insurance or the provincial government that don’t meet their needs.

Name: China: Earthquake-2013
Summary__c: On April 20, 2013 a 7.0 magnitude earthquake struck China’s south-western Sichuan Province.  Over 3,500 aftershocks were reported with many registering over magnitude 5.0. The earthquake affected over 2.8 million people across 17 counties causing over 200 deaths and 14,000 injuries. Approximately 140,000 houses collapsed and the earthquake damaged thousands of miles of roads and hundreds of bridges.

Name: Philippines Central Visayas Earthquake-2013
Summary__c: On the morning of October 15, 2013, a magnitude 7.2 earthquake struck the Central Visayas region of the Philippines. The quake was the strongest to hit the area in more than 20 years and left 222 people dead and 976 injured. Five months later, significant shelter needs remain. According to the Philippines government, the earthquake damaged or destroyed 370,000 homes. The quake also caused extensive damage to public health facilities and schools, as well as electric power failures and disruptions, which interrupted water supply. From November 2013 to January 2014, severe weather disturbances, including heavy rains, floods, and aftershocks, further exacerbated the vulnerability of the earthquake-affected areas. The weather situation has since improved, and electricity has been restored in these areas.

Name: Mexico Storms and Floods-2013
Summary__c: Hurricanes Manuel and Ingrid struck the Pacific and Gulf coasts of Mexico almost simultaneously in mid-September 2013. The state of Guerrero was the most heavily impacted, though two thirds of Mexico’s states dealt with the effects of the hurricanes, including rain, flooding, high winds, and landslides. Severe damage to infrastructure, including roads and airports, slowed emergency access to affected areas and hindered communication. The Mexican government reports the storms caused more than 165 deaths and prompted the evacuation of 36,000 people, including  an estimated 14,000 people into evacuation shelters.  Approximately 26,000 houses were affected, 3,850 of which were severely damaged.

Name: Marshall Islands Drought-2013
Summary__c: In May 2013 the government declared a state of disaster for 13 islands whose communities were severely affected by the drought and faced potential health, environmental, social and economic hardship.  The drought is reported to be affecting 6,400 people across 15 islands north of the capital Majuro. The most significant operational challenge continues to be logistics. Many locations can only be reached by boat, which can involve several days travel and is highly dependent upon weather conditions. Due to the lack of availability and high cost of transport by boat and aircraft, these communities depend upon locally grown crops, which have been badly damaged by the drought, creating the threat of serious food shortages.

Name: Bangladesh Tropical Cyclone-2013
