Summary__c: On May 16, 2013 Cyclone Mahsen made landfall in southern Bangladesh and Myanmar. Strong winds and flooding affected 1.5 million people in Bangladesh and killed 17. Over 26,000 houses were destroyed and over 124,000 were damaged. Over one million people were evacuated to cyclone shelters and, though most people have returned home, some remain in makeshift shelters or outside. Currently, the greatest needs are for shelter, essential household items, clean water and food.

Name: Namibia Drought-2013
Summary__c: Namibia is suffering from severe drought conditions after one of the driest rainy seasons in decades.  The lack of available water is causing a strain on local farmers resulting in food shortage and loss of livestock. The Government of Namibia issued a national state of emergency in May 2013, seeking international assistance for the estimated 331,000 people in rural communities affected by the drought. An inter-agency emergency assessment lead by the Namibian Directorate of Disaster Risk Management indicates that agricultural production will be very poor as a result of the below average rainfall. Cases of cholera and malnutrition are increasing, likely due to the shortage of safe water sources and poor sanitation and hygiene practices.

Name: Indonesia Aceh Earthquake-2013
Summary__c: A 6.2 magnitude earthquake hit Aceh province, Indonesia on July 2, 2013, affecting more than 52,000 people and damaging more than 16,500 houses. The districts of Bener Meriah and Central Aceh sustained the most damage from the earthquake. As of July 18, 2013, 42 deaths had been reported and a more than 2,500 people reported suffering injuries. Access to the affected regions has been a challenge in the response operation, due to narrow roads and a risk of landslides. Many of the main roads in the affected area remain damaged or blocked by debris. The earthquake damaged hospitals and schools and interrupted electricity and communication networks.

Name: Philippines Typhoons and Floods-2013
Summary__c: Starting on August 8, 2013, Typhoon Utor hit Manila and surrounding Philippines provinces, causing 11 deaths and damaging 11,000 homes. A week later, monsoon rains fuelled by Tropical Storm Trami (locally named Maring) flooded the same region. The rains caused major damage to houses, roads and infrastructure. Flooding affected 3 million people over five regions and killed 27. In the final months of 2013, an additional nine storms impacted the previously-affected areas. Some of the affected provinces have been hit repeatedly by the series of storms, leaving a total of five million people affected and at least 126,000 houses damaged. In addition to the damage to household items, livelihoods and shelters, the severe tropical storms brought health concerns. In all, the severe weather events that have occurred since August 2013 left at least 6,200 people dead and damaged more than a million houses across the country.

Name: Vietnam Typhoon Wutip-2013
Summary__c: On September 30, 2013, Typhoon Wutip made landfall in Vietnam as a Category 1 typhoon bringing strong winds, heavy rains and flooding. With sustained winds of 72 miles per hour, experts say Typhoon Wutip is the strongest storm to strike Vietnam since 2006. The storm damaged homes, health centers, schools and power lines and caused losses in crops and livestock in six central provinces of Vietnam. Specifically, some 374 houses collapsed, more than 212,000 houses were damaged and more than 43,000 houses were submerged. Over 119,000 people have been affected, including 11 dead and 214 injured. This storm was followed by Typhoon Nari on October 15, which also made landfall in Vietnam as a Category 1 storm, affecting the coastal provinces and the central highlands. Nine people were killed and more than 120,000 evacuated.

Name: Paraguay Floods-2014
Summary__c: Since March 2014, intense rains in Paraguay have led to severe flooding in rural communities and urban areas along the Paraná River and Paraguay River. The Municipality of Asunción, the capital city located on the left bank of the Paraguay River, declared a state of emergency on July 3 due to the flooding. To date, 231,000 people from five districts in the country require humanitarian support due to the flooding. The impact on inhabitants’ livelihoods is of particular concern, as pastures and agricultural fields have flooded in affected areas where cattle ranching and agriculture are the main economic activities. As the river levels remain high and a new cold front arrives, the situation is expected to worsen. In the Chaco region, many communities remain isolated due to their inaccessibility by land, and authorities anticipate that the displaced persons will remain in temporary shelters at least until the end of the year.

Name: Bangladesh Floods-2014
Summary__c: Since August 13, continuous rainfall in north and north-eastern Bangladesh, together with the onrush of water from upstream rivers, has caused flash floods in low-lying and densely population areas. As of September 1, the number of affected people is 2.8 million. Among these, more than 275,000 are displaced, including more than 150,000 people whose homes have been totally inundated and destroyed. A total of 99 flood shelters are active in the affected districts, housing some of the displaced population while others have settled in along elevated roads and with host families. According to the latest government report, all flood levels are currently receding, with the exception of the upper parts of the Meghana River in the north-eastern region of the country. As the monsoon season extends to October, there is potential risk of a protracted or even worsening situation. With major damage to housing, agriculture, harvest and therefore disruptions to regular livelihoods, the recovery needs following this flooding will be significant. Other major needs include shelter, water and sanitation, health care and food security.

Name: Burundi Population Movement-2012
Summary__c: During the past decade over 525,000 Burundian refugees have voluntarily returned home, while more than 94,000 still remain in neighboring countries, including Tanzania. In 2011, the Tanzanian Government informed its partners that it would close one of its refugee camps by the end of 2012 and repatriate all the Burundian refugees living in that camp. Many of the returnees have experienced been in exile for twenty years. A considerable percentage of the returnees have never lived in Burundi, complicating an already difficult situation. Challenges faced by returnees include redistributed land, shifts in social or commercial systems and changes to social networks. Refugees who have been dependent on humanitarian aid for many years in the refugee camps will now need to find work and support their families in an unfamiliar environment. During the process of repatriation, some families have also been separated and need help to reconnect.

Name: Nepal Floods and Landslides-2014
Summary__c: The monsoon season of 2014 in Nepal has been severe compared to previous years. The monsoon reached Nepal in June and is forecasted to withdraw by late September or early October. After an initial normal start to the season, with only localized flooding, early August saw massive landslides from the hillside in Jure, Mankhaa village of Sindhupalchok district due to heavy rains. In addition to the normal, ongoing monsoon rains, heavy rains between August 14 and 16 have now caused mssive flooding and several landslides in 19 districts throughout the country.

Name: Chile: Earthquake-2014
Summary__c: On April 1, 2014, an 8.2 magnitude earthquake occurred off the coast of northern Chile, the largest in a sequence of earthquakes in northern Chile that started in January 2014. Authorities issued a tsunami alert for Chile and surrounding countries following the earthquake. An aftershock of 7.6 magnitude occurred the next day. The earthquake and its aftershock affected approximately 500,000 people, killing six. Close to one million people in areas with high tsunami risk on the coast of Chile were evacuated. The earthquake damaged 9,400 houses, caused interruptions in the power and utility network and produced minor flooding and landslides.

Name: Solomon Islands Floods-2014
Summary__c: Prolonged heavy rainfall associated with a tropical depression, which later became Tropical Cyclone Ita, passing over the Solomon Islands on April 3, 2014 resulted in severe flooding in the capital, Honiara, and associated damage in Guadalcanal, Makira, Malaita and Isabel provinces. River systems across the northwest, central and north of the island flooded, destroying homes, damaging bridges, blocking roads, and displacing families. A total of 21 people are confirmed dead, 25 missing and an estimated 52,000 people affected across the Solomon Islands, around half of which are children (approx. 10 percent of population).

Name: Central African Republic Civil Unrest-2013
Summary__c: Clashes between former members of the Seleka movement and opposing anti-Balaka groups started in September 2013 and exacerbated the already serious humanitarian situation in the Central African Republic (CAR). Despite the establishment of a new interim government in January 2014, tensions remain high and clashes continue, with ongoing attacks against civilians. While relief agencies are working to assist conflict-affected populations, ongoing insecurity and logistical constraints impede humanitarian operations in the capital, Bangui, and in more remote areas of CAR. Security concerns, including attacks on humanitarian workers, lootings and carjacking, have multiplied over the past months, compromising the delivery of much needed humanitarian aid.  Damaged health and community infrastructure has restricted access to essential services, particularly for wounded and displaced people. Priority needs of those affected include food, shelter, security, and relief items. Almost all internally displaced persons are eating less and using depleted savings to buy food.

Name: Balkans Floods-2014
Summary__c: Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH) have been affected by cyclone Tamara experiencing extremely heavy rain, strong winds and low temperatures. On 13 May, continuous, heavy rainfall began, and the region recorded three months’ worth of rain in three days. It is the worst rainfall recorded in BiH since 1894. In BiH, more than 40% of the country is under water. It is estimated 1,000,000 have been affected by floods and landslides in Bosnia and more than 1.6 million is Serbia.

Name: Kenya Drought-2014
Summary__c: After a poor performance of the long rains between March and May 2014 in the arid and semi-arid zones, the drought situation continued to affect both pastoral and marginal agriculture livelihood zones affecting household food availability as well as livestock productivity. The situation continues to worse due to the increase in food prices which have continually eroded household purchasing power driven by increase in costs of fuel and general inflation.

Name: Sudan: Floods-2013
Summary__c: Annual flooding during the July - September rainy season in Sudan is a reoccurring challenge for many families in different parts of the country. However, in 2013, the rains and subsequent floods were heavier and more extensive, affecting nearly half a million people countrywide, according to the Humanitarian Aid Commission (HAC) of Sudan. The floods destroyed/damaged over 85,000 houses.

Name: Turkey Earthquake-2011
Summary__c: On October 23rd a magnitude 7.2 earthquake struck a highly populated area of Van province in eastern Turkey, killing hundreds, toppling buildings and destroying infrastructure.

Name: Colombia Floods-2010
Summary__c: Colombia suffered an uncommonly long rainy season due to the effects of the La Niña weather phenomenon, with heavy rains continuing for more than eight months. The resulting floods have affected 28 of the 32 departments in the country, triggered landslides and destroyed infrastructure, homes and crops.

Name: Nigeria Complex Emergency-2014
Summary__c: The insurgency situation in the entire North-East part of Nigeria continues deteriorating. The number of internally displaced persons (IDPs) has risen to over a million according to the National Emergency Management (NEMA) while the number of refugees in the three neighbouring countries - Cameroun, Niger and Chad is just over 120,000 people, mostly women and girls. Borno, the hardest hit State in the North-East continues to experience humanitarian challenges and increased needs within the 26 formal and informal IDP camps in the state capital, Maiduguri. Out of 27 Local Government Areas (LGAs) of the states, 20 are now partially under the control of insurgents.

Name: Sudan Complex Emergency-2012
Summary__c: Sudan continues to experience both natural and manmade disasters ranging from conflict, droughts, floods and epidemic outbreaks, creating a cycle of displacement and vulnerability across the country. By the end of 2012, 4.4 million people were estimated to be in need of humanitarian assistance, and these numbers have continued to remain high in the first part of 2013.

Name: Cameroon Population Movement-2014
Summary__c: The Far North Region of Cameroon has been experiencing population movement since 2006 with. From July 2014, a large number of Nigerian refugees have been crossing the border into Cameroon, fleeing the conflict the crisis in Chad and now with the political instability from the North east of Nigeria.48,000 refugees have been identified by the authorities, 34,996 checked and registered by UNHCR since May 2013, including 24,667 in the Minawao camp, 9,829 registered in the border areas of the Far North Region awaiting transfer to the camp, and 4,470 new arrivals to the camp two weeks ago, including 2,918 transferred from Mozogo and Mokolo (Mayo Tsanaga Division) and 1,552 spontaneously arrived the camp. The camp presently hosts 24,667 refugees1 .

Name: Republic of South Sudan - Complex Emergency-2013
Summary__c: The internal conflict that started in the capital city of Juba in South Sudan on 15 December 2013 rapidly spread to other parts of the country. The conflict created long term humanitarian consequences for the affected population, including large displacement in South Sudan and in neighbouring countries (Uganda, Ethiopia, Sudan and Kenya). Despite ongoing negotiations and a recent commitment to peace, the situation remains tense and unpredictable, in particular in the Jonglei, Unity, and Upper Nile states. According to OCHA as of 8 January 2015 approximately 1.5 million people remain displaced: 1.1 million internally and over 434,000 in neighbouring countries.

Name: Niger Population Movement-2014
Summary__c: Since July 2014, the Diffa region in Niger has received approximately 800 displaced persons from Northern Nigeria each week. As of 24 September, the total number of displaced population from Nigeria was 105,000, most of them women and children. Since the beginning of September, more than 16,500 people have reached Diffa region, compared to 10,500 in August. The new arrivals are in urgent need of emergency assistance - food, basic non-food items, emergency shelter, medical assistance, potable water and protection.

Name: Sri Lanka Support for IDPs-2010
Summary__c: All the districts of the Northern Province have been affected by three decades of conflict; the entire Kilinochchi and Mullaitivu districts were fully deserted with all inhabitants displaced and with partial displacements in other districts in the north. Over half a million people had been displaced and lost almost everything. More than five years since the end of the conflict in 2009, a majority of the people displaced have returned to their home areas. The government and partners have committed significant resources to help former IDPs to resettle and reconstruct houses. There are no ‘new IDPs’ living in camps in the country.

Name: Ethiopia Population Movement-2015
Summary__c: Violence in South Sudan since December 2013  is creating a complex humanitarian crisis, with a large flux of refugees into Ethiopia. Ethiopia now has the largest number of refugees in Africa, with approximately 644,000 refugees. 196,500 of thse are from Sound Sudan. A majority of the refugee camps in Ethiopia have reached, or are reaching full capacity. Main concerns include building a new refugee camp, malnutrition among refugees, as well as critical shortfalls in humanitarian aid.

Name: Ethiopia Drought-2015
Summary__c: Failed rains and erratic weather conditions have resulted in severe food insecurity in the north and north east regions of Ethiopia, affecting an estimated 8.2 million people. Initial assessments indicate that the drought could impact as many as 15 million people in 2016.

Name: Honduras Drought-2014
Summary__c: As of June 2014, levels of accumulated rainfall in affected areas in Honduras and other Central American regions have been 50 to 75 per cent below the average. The water shortage has caused crop losses as well as a decrease in the purchasing power of families living in the affected areas. Losses during the first harvest are estimated to be between 17 and 44 per cent, while losses to subsistence farmers in the most affected areas are expected to exceed 70 per cent. Extremely poor households in Honduras will experience a rapid deterioration in food security due to the poor harvest forecast for 2014 and the faster than normal rise in the prices of basic goods.

Name: Mexico Hurricane Odile-2014
Summary__c: The heaviest impact of the Hurricane Odile in Cabo hit late on September 14th, when it made landfall as a Hurricane 3 storm.  The system then became a Tropical Storm which slowly moved up the Peninsula, which made some initial activities within the first 24 hours after initial impact difficult. This particular storm has the added complication of being closely followed by Tropical Storm Polo, which did not make landfall, but will bring additional rain and high winds to the already impacted areas of the peninsula.
